title-group.article-title: Increased heart rate variability during nondirective meditation

article-meta.aff: 3Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Norway.

author-notes.corresp: A Nesvold, Department of Cardiology, Oslo University Hospital, pb 4959 Nydalen, 0424 Oslo, Norway Email: annesv@ous-HF.no

permissions.copyright-statement: © The European Society of Cardiology 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Purpose: Meditation practices are in use for relaxation and stress reduction. Some studies indicate beneficial cardiovascular health effects of meditation. The effects on the autonomous nervous system seem to vary among techniques. The purpose of the present study was to identify autonomic nerve activity changes during nondirective meditation.

Materials and methods: Heart rate variability (HRV), blood pressure variability (BPV), and baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) were monitored in 27 middle-aged healthy participants of both genders, first during 20 min regular rest with eyes closed, thereafter practising Acem meditation for 20 min. Haemodynamic and autonomic data were collected continuously (beat-to-beat) and non-invasively. HRV and BPV parameters were estimated by power spectral analyses, computed by an autoregressive model. Spontaneous activity of baroreceptors were determined by the sequence method. Primary outcomes were changes in HRV, BPV, and BRS between rest and meditation.

Results: HRV increased in the low-frequency (LF) and high-frequency (HF) bands during meditation, compared with rest (p = 0.014, 0.013, respectively). Power spectral density of the RR-intervals increased as well (p = 0.012). LF/HF ratio decreased non-significantly, and a reduction of LF-BPV power was observed during meditation (p < 0.001). There was no significant difference in BRS. Respiration and heart rates remained unchanged. Blood pressure increased slightly during meditation.

Conclusion: There is an increased parasympathetic and reduced sympathetic nerve activity and increased overall HRV, while practising the technique. Hence, nondirective meditation by the middle aged may contribute towards a reduction of cardiovascular risk.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the last 40 years, various meditation techniques have been widely accepted in Western cultures and gradually become object of scientific scrutiny. Since the 1970s, several studies have focused on concentrative meditation techniques and transcendental meditation (TM).1,2 Over the past decade, a shift towards various mindfulness meditations3,4 and nondirective meditation5 has occurred. Beneficial health effects of meditation are often attributed to positive changes in autonomous nerve activity, manifesting as reduced heart and respiratory rates, reduced oxygen uptake, and reduced circulating plasma catecholamine levels.6,7 Several authors report changes in heart rate variability (HRV) during concentrative Zen techniques by healthy participants, characterized as reduced sympathetic and increased parasympathetic activity. The latter is known to be respiration dependent, and the effects on sympathetic versus parasympathetic nerve activity may vary among methods related to volitional versus spontaneous breathing and other characteristics of the practice.8–10

One study reported increased HRV by TM compared with health education in patients with stable coronary artery disease.11 HRV is recognized as an independent inverse marker of cardiovascular risk.12–14 Both genders show a decrease in HRV parameters with advancing age. Females have a dominant HF power compared to males until the age of 45–50, possibly a cardioprotective mechanism.15

Since the first description of power spectrum analysis of HRV,16 the frequency domain method has become the preferred utility of assessing the short-term autonomous cardiovascular control systems in subjects with sinus rhythm. Beat-to-beat oscillations in heart rate are induced by signals from the autonomic nervous system. The power spectral density (PSD) analysis provides information of how power (variance) distributes as a function of frequency. Two main frequency components have been identified: (i) the low-frequency spectrum (LF, 0.04–0.15 Hz), determined by mixed sympathetic-parasympathetic activity and baroreflex control, and (ii) the high-frequency spectrum (HF, 0.15–0.4 Hz), linked to parasympathetic (vagal) respiration dependent activity. Their ratio (LF/HF) represents the sympathovagal balance. The PSD of all RR intervals (PSD-RRI) is a quantitative indicator of the short auto-regulatory function, expressing the total variability and indirectly the global activity of the autonomic nervous system.17

Series of beat-to-beat blood pressures (BP) may be spectral analysed the same way as RRI series, and it has been suggested that the low-frequency spectrum of the blood pressure variability (LF-BPV) mirrors sympathetic tone.18

Baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) is a measure of the dynamic autonomous control of the heart rate caused by variations in BP, defined as the altered RR interval following changes in systolic blood pressure (ms/mmHg). BRS decreases when the autonomic balance is dominated by sympathetic activity and increases through parasympathetic dominance.19,20

An editorial in BMJ 2003 stated that the overall evidence of therapeutic effects of meditation is weak.21 A more recent meta-analysis concluded that scientific research on meditation practices must adhere to more rigorous design, execution, and analysis of results.22 In order to explore meditation scientifically, five methodological criteria have been suggested.23

Acem meditation is a nondirective technique widespread in Scandinavia. It is based on a Western approach, and psychological understanding of the elicited mental processes. The method complies with Cardoso’s criteria for quality meditation research. Acem meditation does not require volitional direction of attention towards specific subjective states of mind, nor any attempts to control the current mental content. Thus, it is practised with a free mental attitude, similar to some mindfulness meditations, and allows any emerging thought, memory, emotion, or sensation to pass through the awareness of the practitioner. Further, it allows spontaneous normal breathing.24 Previous studies on Acem meditation have demonstrated autonomous effects, such as lowering of heart rate during meditation.25

The purpose of the present study was to identify autonomic nerve activity changes by measuring HRV, LF-BPV, and BRS during nondirective meditation compared with regular rest in middle-aged participants of both genders.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 27 middle-aged participants (mean age 53.1, range 34–63 years; 14 males) were studied. All were gainfully employed, had incorporated the meditation practice into their daily routines and were experienced meditators (mean 31, range 10–41 years). Inclusion criteria were freedom from known cardiovascular disease, no concomitant vasoactive or psychotropic medication, and sinus rhythm.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: Registrations were obtained between 09:00 and 13:00. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) was taken in the supine position. The participants rested sitting for 20 min in a quiet semi-darkened room with their eyes closed, allowing thoughts to wander without performing any meditation tasks. After a short interval (about 1 min), the participants started 20 min of Acem meditation. Each served as his/her own control. Haemodynamic and autonomic data were collected continuously (beat-to-beat) and non-invasively with the Task Force Monitor (TFM; version 2.2.11.0, CNSsystems, Medizintechnik, Graz, Austria). A bipolar two-channel continuous ECG was recorded with electrodes on the shoulders and hips and watched by the observer present. An extensive haemodynamic profile was derived by impedance cardiography through band electrodes in the neck and on both sides of the lower thorax and one neutral on the right leg. Continuous arterial BP was measured by two cuffs around the ground phalanxes of the index and middle fingers of one hand, connected to the monitor via a transducer strapped to the lower arm. Every other minute, oscillometric arterial BP was measured automatically with a cuff around the contralateral upper arm.

HRV was estimated by power spectral analysis of the RR intervals. The variations of RRI (i.e. power) within a given time frame were computed mathematically and expressed by amplitude (ms2/Hz) versus frequency (Hz). Spectral analysis of the LF-BPV estimated the low-frequency density (0.04–0.15 Hz) of the beat-to-beat diastolic BP signals.

Spectral analyses was performed with a modified Fast Fourier Transformation similar to the one proposed by Bianchi et al.26 The TFM software applies an adaptive autoregressive parameter algorithm.27,28

The spontaneous activity of the baroreceptors was determined by means of the sequence method,29 which analyses and displays rising sequences (rising systolic BP, extended RR intervals) and falling sequences (decreasing systolic BP, shorter RR intervals) separately. All detected rising and falling sequences are numerically registered as events. The TFM with algorithms is thoroughly validated,30,31 and its mode of operation is minimally disturbing to the participant.

The study design aimed to take into consideration several possible confounders. More consistent and apparent effects of meditation have been reported in experienced meditators.32 To minimize circadian variations among the subjects,33 all registrations were undertaken before noon. Due to the small sample, the gender differences in HRV are reported, but not analysed statistically. Only sinus beats were included, as sinus rhythm is necessary for reliable evaluation of the influence on the autonomic nervous system by HRV.34 Coronary artery disease, arterial hypertension in need of treatment, heart failure, and diabetes mellitus are known to reduce HRV,35–38 hence freedom from such diseases was an inclusion criterion. None of the participants used vasoactive medication, which may affect sympathovagal balance.39–43 Before testing, consumption of caffeine, tobacco, or alcohol, all of which negatively affect HRV, was discouraged for at least 24 hours.44–46 Although tables of normal ranges do exist,47,48 autonomic cardiovascular regulation parameters show large inter- and intra-individual variations. Therefore, in the present study, with a small sample size, we opted on a study design in which each participant served as his/her control during rest and meditation, thus constituting two matched groups.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: For each participant, the TFM provided the mean values of haemodynamic and autonomic variables over the two time periods. The difference between the mean value while resting and the mean value when meditating was calculated. For variables with a sufficiently normal distribution, we used the paired Student’s t-test confidence interval for the estimated mean difference, and the paired samples t-test for the hypothesis of no difference. If the distribution was skewed, we estimated the difference between population medians and used the Wilcoxon approximate normal confidence interval and the Wilcoxon matched-pair signed-rank sum test. SPSS version 16.0 and CIA (www.som.soton.ac.uk/cia) were used for statistical analyses.

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: The study was approved by the Regional Ethical Committee of Health Region South of Norway. All participants gave written informed consent. The study did not involve therapeutic intervention or control. Four participants were advised to seek a GP for follow up of their hypertension.

sec.title: Heart rate and blood pressure variability
sec.p:
Compared with rest, both LF and HF power increased significantly during meditation. Similar results were observed in the PSD-RRI. No statistically significant difference between rest and meditation occurred in the LF/HF ratio. However, a LF/HF ratio of 1.3 at rest vs. 0.9 during meditation indicates a relatively stronger parasympathetic mobilization. LF-BPV significantly decreased during meditation (Table 1). For each individual registration of HRV, the software provides a three-dimensional illustration of the variations in the discernible frequency bands. Figure 1 depicts the typical HRV variations during rest and meditation in one male participant, and the PSD-RRI at one point in time. The activity in the LF domain (0.04–0.15 Hz) is relatively high during both sequences. As the participant begins to meditate, a distinct and persistent increase of activity in the HF band (0.15–0.4 Hz) is seen. Respiration and heart rates did not change significantly (Table 2). Of the total number of heartbeats in both groups, 1.3% ectopic beats were excluded at rest, 2% during meditation. Figure 1.
Three-dimensional illustration of representative heart rate variability changes in one male (55) at rest and during Acem meditation The ordinate indicates the percentages of the HRV variations in the discernible frequencies, the abcissa the range of frequencies (Hz) The time axis (right) shows that registration begins at timepoint 1, the participant starts to rest with closed eyes at 2, stops rest after 20 min at 3. He begins to meditate at 4, and stops meditation after 20 min at 5. To the left, the power spectral density (PSD) is displayed as a vertical bar in colours. The actual value is at the point of time shown by red line at 5. The colour of the bar depends on the actual value (red, low PSD; green or blue, high PSD). Table 1.
Median values of spectral analyses of low-frequency blood pressure variability (LF-BPV), low frequency heart rate variability (LF-HRV), high frequency heart rate variability (HF-HRV), and power spectral density (PSD) variables of heart rate variability at rest and during Acem meditation (n = 27)

sec.title: Blood pressure and baroreflex sensitivity
sec.p:
Mean arterial systolic and mean BP increased significantly during meditation, compared with rest, and there was a non-significant increase in the mean diastolic BP (Table 3). Four individuals were identified as clearly hypertensive. One male had mean systolic/diastolic BP 173/107 mmHg at rest and 184/125 mmHg during meditation. The mean BP of the remaining participants was normal, but with a tendency to increase during meditation. BRS, based on a comparable number of events at rest and during meditation, showed no significant difference (Table 4). Table 3.
Mean values of systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial blood pressures (mmHg) at rest and during Acem meditation (n = 27)
Variable Rest Meditation Differencea p-valueb
Systolic BP 125.9 ± 14.0 128.7 ± 15.3 −2.76 (14.67 to −85) 0.006
Diastolic BP 85.7 ± 9.4 87.2 ± 11.4 −1.50 (−3.30 to 0.30) 0.098
Mean BP 96.8 ± 9.8 99.0 ± 11.1 −2.20 (−3.91 to −0.49) 0.014
Values are mean ± standard deviation or mean (95% confidence interval). a
Student t-test confidence interval. b
Paired samples t-test.
Table 4.
Mean of baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) and of the arithmetic mean of all sequences at rest and during Acem meditation (n = 27)
Variable Rest Meditation Differencea p-valueb
BRS (ms/mmHg) 10.4 ± 4.6 9.9 ± 4.5 0.5 (−0.81 to 1.89) 0.42
Number of events 156.2 ± 87.5 164.2 ± 93.6 −7.9 (−28.6 to 12.7) 0.42

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The novelty of this study is the marked increase in general HRV power during non-directive meditation in middle-aged to elderly participants of both genders. Both the LF and HF components increased, as well as the PSD-RRI, when compared with rest. There was a relatively stronger parasympathetic mobilization. The significant reduction in LF-BPV substantiates the reduced sympathetic tone.

Figure 1 illustrates the findings representatively. It shows that nondirective meditation is not psychobiologically inert and it supports the idea that certain forms of meditation may induce active, rather than quiescent, cardiac dynamics.49,50 The figure aptly depicts the subjective experience of the performer: the peaks and lows may correlate with the variations in the stream of consciousness.

The respiration rate did not differ between rest and meditation. This shows that the HRV changes observed in this study were in fact caused by the mental technique and not by slow breathing, as observed in other techniques.51,52

In line with previous findings from other meditation techniques, no substantial change in the acute mean heart rate was observed, which supports the notion that HR is of limited value in assessing the complex dynamics of meditation effects.53

The increase in blood pressure during meditation merits comment. No description of beat-to-beat BP variations during meditation is found in the literature In the meta-analysis by Ospina et al.22 three studies compared TM with no treatment (NT), including a total of 129 healthy participants (TM = 67, NT = 65) over 3−12 months. The combined estimate of changes in BP showed a small, but non-significant improvement (reduction) in favour of no treatment. Two other studies22 compared TM with concentrative progressive muscle relaxation (PMR), involving a total of 179 hypertensive patients (TM = 90, PMR = 89). A combined estimate of changes in sBP indicated a significant reduction in favour of TM. Long-term reduction in BP in daily life has also been demonstrated with Acem meditation.54

In the present sample, four participants had hypertension, they did not fulfil one inclusion criterion. However, as they were unaware of their condition at inclusion, and as the percentage of hypertensives in the sample (about 15%) reflects that of the general non-treated adult population, their data were included for statistical analysis. As a group, the four hypertensive individuals (resting BP >130/100 mmHg) had equal median LF-BPV, lower median LF-HRV and HF-HRV, but higher median PSD at rest and during meditation than the normotensives. Their mean respiratory and heart rates were higher during both sequences. No significant change in BRS between rest and meditation emerged when the hypertensive individuals were excluded from analysis. Hypertension is known to impair autonomic function parameters substantially, particularly in postmenopausal females.55 Hence, one may argue that the presence of hypertensive participants makes the HRV findings even more robust.

The median LF-BPV at rest and during mediation was almost equal between the genders. The females had lower median LF-HRV during both sequences, still there was a notable increase in both gender groups (median LF-HRV females at rest 155 ms2, during meditation 166 ms2, males at rest 270 ms2, during meditation 282 ms2). For both genders, median HF-HRV was fairly equal during both sequences. The males had a more pronounced increase in median PSD during meditation.

None of the participants had known coronary artery disease (CAD). A possible clinical implication of the HRV findings involves patients with CAD. Intensive supervised relaxation practice after a cardiac ischaemic event has been shown to enhance recovery and contribute to secondary prevention, being an important ingredient of cardiac rehabilitation. Increased HRV seems to be an important measure of successful secondary prevention.56,57

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: There was no non-meditating control group and it was not prospective. All participants were experienced meditators. Thus, the findings give little information about the effects for beginners, and for patients at risk.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Nondirective meditation reduces sympathetic and increases parasympathetic nerve activity and overall HRV in the middle aged of both genders. Regular practice may help to preserve HRV for those of middle age and older, and thus may contribute to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and risk. Further scientific scrutiny should be directed to a larger prospective study involving novice meditators and patients at risk, with a non-meditating control group.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: Of the authors, Anders Nesvold, Svend Davanger, Øyvind Ellingsen, Erik E Solberg and Are Holen are affliliated with Acem School of Meditation, an international non-for-profit organization. Morten W Fagerland, Knut Sevre and Dan Atar have no such affiliation.

Parts of the work have been presented as a poster (P-20) at the International Society for Heart Research (ISHR) North American Section Meeting, 26 May 2009, Baltimore MD, USA and a poster (P-013) at the annual meeting of the Norwegian Society of Cardiology, 8 June 2010, Oslo, Norway.
